Posts.Content: So, I was reading O'hill's post, and down in the comments she mentions Weightwatchers, one word. Only the censors take some of the letters out. Perhaps they will on my post too, so I won't ruin it. I looked at the word for a while, imagining the missing letters till I figured it out. Dang. That was a good laugh. If the censors didn't get it this time, look below for the version I saw. Weigh****chers. Hee Hee Hee, Joyce
Posts.Title: Too funny

Posts.Content: RE, you are up to 400 cc's. Wow. I've been doing this for months and am at about 220. I did go to the bra shop for women without and get pads for both sides to try to even out my profile. Better, not perfect. And as far as the weight gain goes, I am not surprised. I am sure that my plst. surg. is using cement, not saline on this breast rock I have. But as far as swimming, I think not. First of all, without the bust building foam I would look weird indeed and with it I would float till it soaked up water like a sponge, and then sink like a rock. Wow, the image of going under and having to shed my breasts to save my life is just a little to close to what has actually happened in my life! Mimi, loved your attitude. I did a little strutting today in my new bra. As a "smaller" woman, I have always considered padding to be cheating, but tempting. Now I can say its not vanity, it's a MEDICAL necessity! So there! Pass the clingy sweater, please. love, Joyce
Posts.Title: CONFESSIONS OF A GOOF

Posts.Content: Okay, I give up. This is regarding editing the preferences for this site on my personal info page. I have tried every different configuration of settings and I am still getting email notifications of every post on the site. I check the site daily and would rather not also have, say, 25 messages a day about new posts in my email box. And now I have messed with it so much I don't get notified on my CSN screen of when I have a personal CSN mail. What does "check here to autosubscribe to any post you initiate" mean? I have both checked and unchecked this box and nothing changes. Do all of you also get all the notifications for each post? Is anyone else suffering through this or have all of you figured it out? Signed, Hopeless... or, Stuck in the last century...or, Not Ready for Facebook Yet...
Posts.Title: Not the sharpest tool

Posts.Content: I am nine months into my year of herceptin and have no side effects at all from that. Taxol wasn't as bad for me as it was for some others - everyone is different. But if you look back, you will see a post like yours from me asking what to expect as I went into the taxol. It just have been so nice to know! Honestly, though, one of the good things that came out of this awful BC DX was learning to take it one day at a time. It got my through TX and as a wonderful parting gift is helping me enjoy my life every day afterwards. Do not tax your body in anyway during your treatments with a weight loss plan that isn't completely healthy, and doctor approved. Our bodies are working so hard already to get us through chemo. Remember to love yourself during this time. And plan for weight loss later. I used to fantasize about how beautiful I was going to be when my hair grew back (and my toenails - you may lose those from the taxol). The fantasizing was a way of soothing my body and self. love, Joyce
Posts.Title: What side effects with Taxol and Herceptin?

Posts.Content: Tan, please listen to your body. It will tell you what you need and every "body" is different. I am a go go girl too. Sometimes I didn't feel like slowing down when everyone thought I should. Other times, I feel like being a baby when there is nothing "others" can see wrong. Your body has been through a lot and is a good friend. Just listen to it, do what you feel is good for it, give it what it asks for and thank people politely for their advice. You have earned the right to be your own boss now. I wish you all the best! love, Joyce
Posts.Title: when do the aches and pains go away?

Posts.Content: CR - I had a mas. and do not remember having much swelling. If the swelling is from build up of fluids that should have been draining, maybe doc. needs to take a look. And heat can be a sign of infection. Other women may tell you different - this is just my experience. Also, in my experience, healing went pretty fast. And do not think that the scar you see now is the one you will get. Mine continued to fade for months and is pretty unnoticable now by comparison. But please read on for other opinions. love, Joyce
Posts.Title: Problem with swelling...

Posts.Content: Mimi is right about taking something. Ativan was prescribed to me and there were some times when it came in useful. Including before my chemo treatments. I also had a Pet Scan. I do not know if cells were found in my blood stream. Getting both a Pet Scan and a bone scan were normal procedure. I had the same treatment as you, two weeks apart followed by radiation. There were times when I thought my onc. was trying to scare me a little. Later I found out that she just wanted to be sure I didn't opt out of chemo/rads like some people do. Opt out, heck, I was glad to get them. I already thought I was gonna die. I can't believe that some people would not be scared %^$*less (my censor) so for me the tough talk just wasn't necessary to bring me down to brass tacks. I wish you good things, and good news. Love, Joyce
Posts.Title: + on Lymph Nodes => Blood Vessel => PET scan

Posts.Content: Margo, I read the story and it was love(ly). I am moved to give you some advice that I can't take myself, but still it is a goal, sometimes. I am moved to do this thing because you are already following this advice. It is as follows: What ever you are forced to do with this treatment, look for a way to do it that will bless you, your family, or others. This is what has happened with your hair cut. It is some kind of triumph, huh, when we can take something not so good and find in it some good and bring that forth. Congratulations to you and your son for your style and thanks for reminding me to have a little more too! love, Joyce
Posts.Title: Son supported MOM today

Posts.Content: This reply is going to be not very helpful, because I haven't had a histerectomy (sp). But I wanted to say when I got my DX, had my mas. went into chemo menopause, knew I would be taking tamoxifin I felt like I was swapping in my female card. I was sure that scary things would happen to my sexuality not to mention my looks. Well, they didn't. I am still me. I still strut my stuff (though I only have half a deck!)and I still feel feminine. What I want to say is that I think all these things sound scarier and more damaging than they are. One of my friends, who is no slouch, had a hist. years ago and she is still very beautiful (and a little too active for her own good!). My yoga teacher who is gorgeous casually mentioned she had a hist. a long time ago. I am just typing all the good stories I can so that maybe they can counteract some of the scary images that we can so easily dream up. Courage, darling, and one day at a time. Don't worry, you'll always be Heather the nut! Oh, and I did get hot flashes but they are almost completely gone now. Meanwhile another friend who was naturally menopausal is still going through year two of hers. I wish you ease, hope, health and beauty. Love, Joyce
Posts.Title: I may have already posted this but 125ca #'s up!!!

Posts.Content: There is a walk in clinic at Kaiser. That is how I managed my last mammo. Just walked in without having to schedule and worry ahead of time. Now I just need to wait out the we'll call you if we have terrible news phase. But, if and when I get the all clear, the feeling of relief will be worth it. As bad as anticipating it seems is as good as getting it over is gonna seem. And we will be right here if you want to complain a little. I did (see not balanced yet post), just recently, but still, I am glad I went. love you, and I understand, Joyce
Posts.Title: Do I HAVE to have a Mammogram?

Posts.Content: Yes. Thank you. To all of you. I am so grateful for every kind, creative, funny, and heartfelt word on this site. Today I had a little ouchie when suddenly in the middle of a work seminar I thought "how are the other people here seeing me - first and foremost as that poor woman who has breast cancer?" And it hurt. And then I thought of all of you, each facing this ouchie in your own lives. And the unity I felt with you all was so much bigger than the alienation I got from my thought. You make me feel like those cell phone adds where the users have "people", standing with them. We stand together. My new normal includes the idea that I am part of this group. And I am so proud of it! love, Joyce
Posts.Title: THANK YOU!

Posts.Content: Cathy, I got a nice after surgery bra from Nordstroms for 28 bucks, cotton, closes in the front, recommended by my doc. My husband had to run out and buy it because I forgot to plan ahead and the underwires were forbidden. I also sent him out for some soft dressing pads. My doc. said I could use sanitary pads against the wound, but I didn't have the heart to make my husband buy me both a bra AND feminine protection in one trip! Also, this is a very small detail, but I have found that if I take a long, wide, ace bandage and make a sash (wrapped twice or more) for my waist with the drain held against my skin, I feel much more secure than having the dang thing dangling, and it is easier to dress around too. It is now four days since my surgery and I walked several blocks today and feel very much over the hump, though I am still quite tender and careful. I wish you an easy time of it! Take care, love Joyce
Posts.Title: DIEP reconstruction

Posts.Content: Glad to hear you are doing well. Sounds like the surgery wasn't too tough. It does take time, doesn't it? I laugh at how I thought plastic surgeons were able to make everyone into Victoria's secret models over night. And I also laugh at the new sizing - cc's. I am at 100 after the expander was put in. How does 450 translate in cup size? Thank you so much for writing, your enthusiasm was good for me to hear. love, Joyce
Posts.Title: DIEP reconstruction

Posts.Content: I am so glad, Lili! Let me hug you quick before the surgery and wish you every happiness and a wonderful feeling of triumph! Here's wishing you a quick recovery and a fun trip to Victoria's Secret. love and hugs, Joyce
Posts.Title: DIEP reconstruction

Posts.Content: Please accept my love for you in this difficult time. You are going to have so much to process. We will help you all we can. Please love yourself, be kind to yourself. I can see from your wanting, even in this hard time, to help others that you are a wonderful person. I reached out for help EVERYWHERE. Books, this support group, yoga, crying, I tried it all. Make yourself your number one priority. Surround yourself with good things. And count us in for the long haul. love, Joyce
Posts.Title: 2 losses in 1 week
